title: 107_hr1625
content: The "Samuel Kelner Commission on Youth Authorization Act" establishes a commission to address issues affecting American youth, such as public education, youth employment, higher education financing, and drug abuse. The Commission on Youth is composed of 8 members appointed by various officials, with an age limit of 18 years. Each member serves a 1-year term starting on August 1 and can be reappointed. The Commission on Youth consists of 8 members appointed by officials, serving a 1-year term starting on August 1 and can be reappointed. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings. The Commission on Youth consists of 8 members appointed by officials, serving a 1-year term starting on August 1. The Chairperson is elected by the members. The Commission holds 4 meetings each year, each spanning 3 days, and 1 conference spanning 1 week. The initial meeting starts on the first Thursday in August, with the remaining meeting dates determined by majority vote. The Commission on Youth holds regular meetings and a conference each year. In addition, an emergency meeting of up to 3 days may be called by the President. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR; STAFF; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the President, paid at the rate of basic pay for GS-12. Additional personnel may be appointed as needed. The Director and staff shall be appointed according to title 5, United States Code. The Commission may procure temporary services and federal agencies can detail personnel upon request. The Commission may request personnel from federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties under this Act. The Commission has powers to carry out its duties under this Act. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain necessary information from government agencies to fulfill its duties under the Act. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can use the United States mails as needed. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. The Director has the authority to contract with government and private agencies for necessary supplies and services. The Commission is required to submit an annual report to the President and Congress by July 1 each year, containing policy recommendations on youth-related issues. The Commission will terminate five years after the start of its first members' terms. $100,000 is authorized for the Commission's operations each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006.
